We all need to stay grounded as part of being proactive about our mental health. Try these 5 steps.
#LISAcares #LISAsupports
shared_text:
Stay Positive Arkansas is with Burrell Behavioral Health and 2 others.
September 8 at 1:18 PM ·

Chances are we've all felt overwhelmed at some point recently. Jude Kearney, a Crisis Specialist with Burrell Behavioral Health in Northwest Arkansas, shared one tool he uses to relieve stress and return to the present: Getting Grounded.

Take a few deep breaths and try these steps.

Step 1: Name 1 good thing about yourself.

Step 2: Name 2 things that you can smell around you.

Step 3: Name 3 things that you can hear around you.

Step 4: Name 4 things that you can touch around you.

Step 5: Name 5 things that you can see around you.

John Boozman
August 7 at 9:11 AM ·

Today, on Purple Heart Day, we honor our brave service members who have received this award in recognition of their being killed or wounded in action. We salute these heroes and express our eternal gratitude for their service and sacrifice.

The Purple Heart is the oldest military award still in use. Its predecessor, the Badge for Military Merit, was created by George Washington on this day in 1782.

William Brown and Elijah Churchill were the first soldiers to receive the Badge of Military Merit for their service in the Continental Army during the American Revolution. The first service member to receive the modern-day Purple Heart was Army Gen. Douglas MacArthur. John F. Kennedy is the only president to have received a Purple Heart.

Bunch III, the Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution, Dr. Johnetta Betsch Cole, the first female African American president of Spelman College, and the Honorable Carla Hayden, Librarian of Congress, the first woman and the first African American to lead the national library.

The platform was brought together by the Charles H. Wright Museum of African American History (Detroit, MI), Historic Mitchelville Freedom Park (Hill Head Island, SC), Northwest African American Museum (Seattle, WA), Black Archives Historic Lyric Theater (Miami, FL), National Underground Railroad Freedom Center (Cincinnati, OH), and the National Civil Rights Museum (Memphis, TN).

"Books: A Window into the World During COVID-19
Now more than ever, at a time when globally most schools are closed and people are having to limit time spent out of their homes, the power of books can be leveraged to combat isolation, to reinforce ties between people, and to expand our horizons, while stimulating our minds and creativity.

During the month of April and all year round, it is critical to take the time to read on your own or with your children. It is a time to celebrate the importance of reading, foster children's growth as readers, and promote a lifelong love of literature and integration into the world of work."
